{| class="toccolours" style="margin-left: 1em; float: right; border: 1px solid #CCC;" |+ ''' Polydeuces''' |- ! colspan="2" | [[Image:Polydeuces.jpg|Saturn's moon Polydeuces]]
Saturn's moon Polydeuces. |- ! bgcolor="#a0ffa0" colspan="2" | Discovery |- ! align="left" | Discovered by | [http://ciclops.org/team/iss_team.php Cassini Imaging Science Team] |- ! align="left" | Discovered on | 24 October, 2004 |- ! bgcolor="#a0ffa0" colspan="2" | [[Orbit]]al characteristics |- ! align="left" | mean [[Semimajor axis]] | 377,396 kmref name="Dione"The ''mean'' semi-major axis and period must be identical to [[Dione (moon)|Dione's]]. |- ! align="left" | [[Eccentricity (orbit)|Eccentricity]] | 0.0192ref name="Spitale06"{{cite journal | author= Spitale, J. N.| coauthors= Jacobson, R. A.; [[Carolyn C. Porco|Porco, C. C.]]; and Owen, W. M., Jr.| title= ''The orbits of Saturn's small satellites derived from combined historic and ''Cassini'' imaging observations''| journal= The Astronomical Journal| year= 2006| volume= 132| issue=2 | pages= 692| url= http://www.iop.org/EJ/article/1538-3881/132/2/692/205235.html | doi= 10.1086/505206 }} |- ! align="left" | [[Orbital period]] | 2.736915 dref name="Dione" |- ! align="left" | [[Inclination]] | 0.1774 ± 0.0015°ref name="Spitale06" |- ! align="left" | Is a [[natural satellite|satellite]] of | [[Saturn]] |- ! bgcolor="#a0ffa0" colspan="2" | Physical characteristics |- ! align="left" | Mean [[diameter]] | 3.5 kmref name=PorcoPorco, C. C.; ''et al.''; [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/short/307/5713/1226 ''Cassini Imaging Science: Initial Results on Saturn's Rings and Small Satellites''], Science, Vol. 307, No. 5713 (February 25, 2005), pp. 1226-1236 |- ! align="left" | [[Mass]] | 1 − 5 e13 [[kilogram|kg]] ref name="density"based on density 0.5 − 2 g/cm³ |- ! align="left" | Mean [[density]] | unknown |- ! align="left" | Surface [[gravity]] | unknown |- ! align="left" | [[Sidereal day|Rotation period]] | [[synchronous rotation|assumed synchronous]] |- ! align="left" | [[Axial tilt]] | unknown |- ! align="left" | [[Albedo]] | unknown |- ! align="left" | Surface [[temperature]] | align="center" | {| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="2" border="0" |- ! min !! mean !! max |- | | | |} |- ! align="left" | [[celestial body's atmosphere|Atmosphere]] | none |} '''Polydeuces''' (pronEngˌpɒlɨˈdjuːsiːz respellPOLiDEWseez, or as Greek ''Πολυδεύκης)'' is a very small [[natural satellite]] of [[Saturn]] that is co-orbital with [[Dione (moon)|Dione]] and librates around the trailing [[Lagrangian point]] (L5). Its diameter is estimated to be about 3.5 km.ref name=Porco Polydeuces was discovered by the [http://ciclops.org/team/iss_team.php Cassini Imaging Team] on October 24, 2004ref name="Murray05"{{cite journal | author= Murray, C. D.; ''et al.''| title= ''S/2004 S 5: A new co-orbital companion for Dione''| journal= Icarus| year= 2005| volume= 179| pages= 222| doi= 10.1016/j.icarus.2005.06.009}} in images taken on October 21, 2004,ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/08400/08432.html C.C. Porco, et al., IAUC 8432: ''Satellites and Rings of Saturn''] November 8, 2004 (discovery),ref name=PorcoPorco, C. C.; ''et al.'' (2005), [http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/content/short/307/5713/1226 ''Cassini Imaging Science: Initial Results on Saturn's Rings and Small Satellites''], Science, Vol. 307, No. 5713, pp. 1226-1236 and given the temporary designation '''S/2004 S 5'''. Subsequent searches of earlier Cassini imaging showed it in images as far back as April 9, 2004ref name="Murray05". Polydeuces is also designated as '''Saturn XXXIV'''. Of the known Lagrangian co-orbitals in the Saturn system, Polydeuces wanders the farthest from its Lagrangian point. The [[libration]] takes it away from the L5 by up to 31.4° in the direction away from Dione, and 26.1° towards it with a period of 790.931 days (for comparison L5 trails Dione by 60°).ref name="Spitale06" Polydeuces' libration is large enough that it takes on some qualities of a [[tadpole orbit]], as evidenced by the clear asymmetry between excursions towards and away from Dione. In the course of one such cycle, Polydeuces' orbital radius also varies by about ± 7660 km with respect to Dione's.ref name="Murray05" The name Polydeuces was approved by the IAU Working Group on Planetary System Nomenclature on January 21, 2005.ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/08400/08471.html IAUC 8471: ''Satellites of Saturn''] January 21, 2005 (naming the moon) In [[Greek mythology]], [[Castor and Polydeuces|Polydeuces]] is another name for Pollux, twin brother of [[Castor and Polydeuces|Castor]], son of [[Zeus]] and [[Leda (mythology)|Leda]]. ==References==
